--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Eugene Kuleshov <eu@m...> wrote:
>   By the w=
ay, continuous integration servers (such as
> CruiseControl) would generate=
 a nice report that include
> failed tests along with the list of the chang=
ed sources.
> That may not scale well for a massive code change but
> still=
 provide a good help to find a starting point... or
> narrow down list of g=
uilty developers. :-)

Most often a test failure is due to changes made sin=
ce the last 
clean run.  Yesterday, however, we had a test fail, in Cruise =

Control, while neither the test nor anything it called had been 
changed f=
or months.


(Want a clue?  Well...  Yesterday was the last day of a month;=
 a 
boundary condition.)

So we found an edge case, like the "year 2000" is=
sue, where code can 
fail due to the passage of time, not just changes to t=
he code.


Generally, however, we find that build failures are caused by 
s=
omething in the list of changes Cruise Control reports.
